Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 07:32AM sunflowerE152 wrote: I noticed puffiness in my hand several weeks ago, and then noticed I could not see the veins in my wrist last night.  Then I found this thread this morning and found out it could be lymphedema. I am half way through chemo and looking into reconstruction this summer.  What should be my next step?  My arm is not really bothering me, although I do have numbness in my upper arm.
Posts.Title: VISIBLE SIGNS OF LYMPHEDEMA - A PICTORIAL LindaLou53 glennie19

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 01:31PM sunflowerE152 wrote: Thank you all.  I called my surgeon today and got an appointment for next week.  We are iced in here in Dallas, so when I called her office, she was answering her own phone and I got to talk to her.
Posts.Title: VISIBLE SIGNS OF LYMPHEDEMA - A PICTORIAL LindaLou53 glennie19

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 01:32AM sunflowerE152 wrote: Thanks all.  I saw my surgeon this morning.  She was very supportive and imediately referred me to a LE clinic located in outpatient rehab at the hospital in dallas that seems to do the most breast related surgeries - Presbyterian.  I've checked out their website and all therapist are LANA certified, and my surgeon likes it because it is managed by a retired breast surgeon. Fortunately, I was able to get my evaluation appointment on Monday, and then I can go from there.  It looks like I will have therapy several times a week for three to four weeks, is this pretty standard?  Being a teacher, this is going to be hard - but I do want to get it under control as quickly as possible.  At this point, I do not have a debilitating condition and I don't want it to get that way. Linda - I especially want to thank you for the pictures.  I was suspicious, but busy and consumed with chemo and probably would not have taken action so quickly if not for the pictures on this thread that convinced me that I had lymphadema.  My arms look just like those pictures, and when I went to see my surgeon, there was no question.
Posts.Title: VISIBLE SIGNS OF LYMPHEDEMA - A PICTORIAL LindaLou53 glennie19

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 06:32AM sunflowerE152 wrote: Thanks to Linda and lago and their pictures, I definitely think I have a mild case of lymphadema, and I will see my surgeon next Friday.  I am wanting (needing) to exercise.  What can I do and how do I need to be careful prior to getting compression garments? Or should I go out and get one without a prescription? I was due to start a pilates and yoga combination class Feb 1.  Both Wed and Fri nights were canceled due to the freeze in Dallas.  I want to go on Monday, but of course I don't want to do anything to make things worse.
Posts.Title: VISIBLE SIGNS OF LYMPHEDEMA - A PICTORIAL LindaLou53 glennie19

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2011 07:57AM sunflowerE152 wrote: I first had bc in my right breast in 2002 and had a lumpectomy and radiation.  I September, when I discovered it in my right breast again, I had an MRI and the left brest was still clear.  My surgeon also adviced against removing the left breast and when asked again prior to reconstruction still said no.  I will have to continue to monitor my left breast and will do so with self examination as well as yearly mamograms (I found the bc early on myself both times). With both the MX (October) and DIEP (2.5 wks ago) recovery has been easier with having only one side done.  I am very right handed and have had to do a lot with my left arm, but at least I can still do for myself.  Where if I had had a BMX and bilateral DIEP I would have needed a lot more help.  Not to mention that the surgeries would have been twice as long.  I am doing fine now, but my bp dropped and I got 2 units of blood the night following my DIEP - I don't know what would have happened if the surgery had been 14 hrs instead of 7 hrs. I would encourage you to take your physician's advice.
Posts.Title: Unilateral or Bilateral kmpod 2Nan

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 11:03AM sunflowerE152 wrote: I went back to yoga after mx and recon even after I developed a mild case of LE.  I love yoga, and really need the abdominal and arm work.  Once I got stronger, I liked down dog and was able to do it without making my le worse.  I have now been out of it for 6 wks due to addition recon surgery, and am afraid when I go back it will get worse.  I have only had swelling in my hand, and now that it is cooler it is hardly noticeable - thank goodness.  I will try it again.
Posts.Title: Yoga and LE Sue53 mumito

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 09:57AM sunflowerE152 wrote: You really think the sucking on ice while it was going in had a lasting effect?  If so, I am definitely trying it.  Thanks for the hints lago!
Posts.Title: What tastes good? sunflowerE152 Claire82

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2011 07:37PM sunflowerE152 wrote: I had a UMX, Oct 12th a year ago.  My drain was slow to come out (2-3 wks), but I eventually got below the 25cc per day that my BS required.  I too had to go in and get fluid drained a couple of times, and I was scheduled to begin chemo on Nov 18th.  The day before I went to my BS and was still having fluid build up.  She immediately called my onc and instead of chemo, I got another drain put in.  It was put in by an intervention radiologist.  I had a friend that had an absess after her galblatter surgery and an intervention radiologist put her drain in also.  It wasn't much fun, but Dec 20th I got the best Christmas present ever and had it removed.  Although my surgeon did not limit my activity at all.  I will tell you that it was not until I had another surgery on Dec 9th (my parodid gland removed) and was bed ridden for 72 hours did the fluid stop. My advice would be to limit your activity and ask about inserting another drain.  No one likes them, but it beats the alternative.  My BS seemed puzzled with my fluid, but she would not let ig go.  I had to keep coming back every few days and she was adament that it could not be ignored.
Posts.Title: Healing of Seroma - Need Help! rkt Pattyanne

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 04:29AM sunflowerE152 wrote: At the time, I thought hair loss was the worst, but I am 3 wks post getting a buzz cut and wearing a wig and I'm getting used to it.  I am a high school teacher, and thought it was important for me to look as normal as possible, so I purchased a good synthetic wig.  It is monofilament and has an adjustable cap.  I purchased it at a salon where the styling of it is included in the price, and she cut it to match my original hair style as much as possible.  People that don't know me well and know what I am going through think I just got a new hair style (and color - it's highlighted), I had my wig ready and the first morning I washed my hair and had it shed all over me, I made the decision to go get it cut.  As soon as I made my appt, I ran into a friend whose style I admire and asked her to go with me.  She is also an extremely positive person who has a grown handicapped son.  As we were waiting she mentioned that her sister has worn a wig for 12 years because of permanent hair loss due to a medical condition.  I hope my hair comes back, but in the grand scheme of things, it is rather insignificant. Over the holidays, I read Nancy Brinker's book, Promise me.  I told my onc if he ever needed to convince someone to do chemo, that he should recommend it.  There is a lot of history of the disease, and it made me so grateful to be able to fight it in 2010 and not years ago.  Hopefully our daughters will not have to go through what we are having to go through. I just got a present of classes canceled today for winter weather so I can catch up, since I got so far behind last week recovering from my 2nd tx of TC.  Bless you all who are having to deal with illness Marcia
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 06:47PM sunflowerE152 wrote: Don't know if this will help any of you, but I wear wig liners.  I am so glad it is winter and not summer, because I think it helps with the shedding and itching. Plus my wig seemed a little big without any hair under it and the liner helps keep it in place. At first I went to the place that I got my wig and they gave me some of the nylon ones.  I have since ordered cotton ones from tlc and will wear them under my wig every day.  They are suppose to make it cooler when it gets hot as well.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2011 06:44PM sunflowerE152 wrote: bdavis and Mrs M you look great!  I am 5 months PFC and my hair was about 1.5 inches before I got it trimmed on Saturday.  However, it is very curly and frizzy.  I wash and moose it daily and can sort of stand it.  The moose seems to do better than the gel for me.  I want to know what the best products are for curly frizzy chemo hair if anyone has tried multiple.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 05:53PM sunflowerE152 wrote: I'm now 4.5 months out and my hair is thick and about 1 in long, but curly and very unmanageable.  How long does this stage last?  I'm tempted to trim it - I would rather have short than frizzy unmanageable curls.  Any suggestions?
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 09:37PM sunflowerE152 wrote: I have really thick hair and when it started coming out I went and got it buzzed and started wearing my wig.  I am so glad I did bc it continued to come out and every morning in the shower I scrubbed my scalp and tried to get as much out as possible so I would not have little short hairs all over me.  I never lost it all, but my scalp was very visible and I can't imagine trying to style it.  When people say they never lost their hair, I wonder what percent they really held onto.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 09:39PM sunflowerE152 wrote: Betsy it has been great not having to worry about any hair during DIEP recovery.  Easy to wash and dry for sure:)

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2011 09:42PM sunflowerE152 wrote: I had a lumpectomy and radiation on my rt breast for bc in 2002 and was diagnosed again last year in the same breast - tumor had a different pathology though. This time I have had a UMX and delayed DIEP.  The radiation did complicate things.  I had TEs prior to DIEP to stretch out the radiated skin, and my noob will always be firmer than my left breast bc of the radiation and the tightness of the skin. My Stage 2 is scheduled for Oct 5th to lift the left breast and I am hoping that will be it.
Posts.Title: anyone have mastectomy years afyer radiation? bak94 Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 10:40AM sunflowerE152 wrote: I got mine buzz cut, and then I massaged my scalp in the shower when it was coming out heavily.  It seemed to help with the amount of very short hairs on my clothes and in my hats and wig. I lost a whole lot after the first treatment; however, I still have a lot of hair on my head.  Can I expect to lose more every treatment, or is what is left there to stay?  I was told I might actually need to come in and get it buzz cut again. I "had" very thick hair, which I thought would be a good thing.  However, I decided when it started falling out that it meant there was more hair to fall out and therefore a bigger mess.  Very glad I got it buzzed!
Posts.Title: when losing hair... ninastar Letlet

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2011 05:37PM sunflowerE152 wrote: I can speak to my own experience.  I had DIEP 4 wks ago and I have a mild case of LE.  Immediately after surgery it was concerned because my LE was worse.  I wore my sleeve and glove in the hospital and had an LE therapist come see me b/c my hand puffed up.  In a couple of days it went down and my PS said it should actually get better and it has.  I have always just had some puffiness in my hand and it is almost all gone and is definitely not any worse than it was before my DIEP.  I am no longer wearing my sleeve and glove on a regular basis.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction and risk of lymphedema? Lisbeth SpunkyGirl

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 06:52PM sunflowerE152 wrote: I have had BC twice 2002 - < 2 cm, pre-meno, ER+, no nodes, lumpectomy, radiation, and tamoxifin 2010 - <.5 cm but several places, triple neg, no nodes, mastectomy, and chemo  My surgeon and onc say recommendations have changed in the last 8 years because of what they know about the tumors and that chemo has become more manageable.  Although there are still some dreadful SEs to chemo, the ones that cause dreadful damage to major organs are no longer used for BC.  I am 3/4 of the way through chemo and it has not been that bad. My surgeon also said the other day that she hates to say anything to patients any more about follow up treatments, because the oncologists recommendation might be different, and she doesn't want either of them to look bad.
Posts.Title: Does what my surgeon said sound accurate? BioAdoptMom3 BioAdoptMom3
